Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Regulation of multicellular behavior with an extracellular matrix signaling scaffold

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1150467
Smith, Michael

The research objectives of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project are to determine whether multicellular cultures in both 2D and 3D systems spatially regulate the tension in their extracellular matrix fibronectin fibers in a manner that would spatially control cell behavior and to determine how mechanical forces applied to these matrix fibers in turn regulate the proliferation and directed migration of cells resident within the matrix. The coordination of multicellular behavior is critical to numerous physiological processes such as morphogenesis and wound repair. Although soluble signaling molecules are known to regulate cell behavior over long distances, this project will explore how mechanical tension alters the structure of insoluble proteins that constitute the extracellular matrix.

The highly interdisciplinary and integrative nature of this research will have a transformative impact on a number of fields since cell-cell communication is a basic scientific phenomenon that is critical to numerous aspects of cell biology and physiology. This hypothesis leads to the concept of an insoluble signaling scaffold that can be actively and reversibly tuned by cell contractility and will generate numerous testable hypotheses that upend traditionally held views about cell-cell communication in development, homeostasis, and disease. The multi-level education plan of this CAREER project includes development of a one hour, hands-on activity on cell mechanics that is intended to illustrate the role of scientists and engineers in tackling important societal problems to area high school students and development of a new graduate course entitled Cell Mechanics, Adhesion, and Locomotion, which will cover mechanics from molecular to multicellular length scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The coordination of multicellular behavior is critical to numerous physiological processes such as morphogenesis, angiogenesis, and wound repair. In each of these processes, a complex tissue organization is created from individual components through a process that is tightly regulated both spatially and temporally. The extracellular matrix (ECM) can be characterized by its biochemical, mechanical, and topographical properties, and indeed, cell behavior can be controlled by many properties and features of the ECM. This CAREER facilitated numerous contributions to both the basic science of ECM mechanobiology, which is the field focused on understanding how physical stresses and strains regulate life, as well as training of future scientists and engineers. In addition, an important tool was developed for this work that has been disseminated to other labs focusing on cellular mechanobiology.

First, the basic science contributions of this CAREER resulted in ten peer-reviewed publications. Of those, two manuscripts are reviews/perspectives, and the remaining eight articles are original contributions. All organs and tissues are routinely subjected to routine stretching, and the focus of this CAREER was to determine if mechanically stretching the ECM alters its ability to direct cellular functions such as cell migration or cell proliferation. We discovered that heparin and heparan sulfates as well as mechanical strain co-regulate the conformation of ECM molecules. This work further culminated in a report showing that the degree of strain applied to ECM matrix fibers indeed may result in an integrin switch so that cell attachment, spreading, and migration is greatly reduced. This was a key finding of the CAREER work that addressed a long-standing hypothesis in the field of ECM mechanobiology. Second, this CAREER resulted in the development of a novel tool for cell mechanics/mechanobiology. We developed a tool that uses soft lithography and micropatterning so that it is capable of controlling cell shape, substrate rigidity, the topography of cell adhesion molecules, and mapping cell stiffness after application of substrate stretch. This tool has been freely disseminated to the cell mechanobiology community through publication in peer reviewed journals and distribution of analysis software via the web. Lastly, this CAREER provided numerous training opportunities for young scientists-in-training. Two PhD candidates, twelve undergraduates, two high school students, and a middle school science teacher worked in the lab on this project.
